Scheme 1 (a) Proposed mechanism for the DH of n-octane over MM′ based catalysts under the unsteady state conditions. (b) The proposed structure of the coked catalyst. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 XRD patterns of magnesium molybdate synthesised by the co-precipitation method Catalyst (a) MM′0.87 (b) MM′0.98 (c) MM′1.06 and (d) MM′1.25. MgMoO4 phase assignment: α-MgMoO4 (*), β-MgMoO4 (•) and MoO3 (ᴼ). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Raman spectra of all four catalysts with different magnesium content (a) MM′0.87 ′0.98 (b), MM′1.06 (c) and MM′1.25 (d) showing both phases (*) MoO3 and (•) MgMoO4. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TPR profile for MM′0.87 (a), MM′0.98 (b), MM′1.06 (c) and MM′1.25 (d), obtained using 5% hydrogen as the reducing gas, TPR-O-R cycle for MM′0.98 (e) and MM′1.25, (f) using air as the oxidizing gas. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XPS spectra of magnesium molybdate synthesised by the co-precipitation method. (a) MM′0.87 (b) MM′0.98 (c) MM′1.06 and (d) MM′1.25. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Catalytic results for MgMo catalysts: a) Conversion, b) Selectivity to octene isomers, c) Selectivity to aromatics, d) selectivity to cracked products. (Reaction conditions: Temperature = 550 °C, GHSV = 11 000 h−1 and n-octane concentration in the feed = 11.5%) [Unsteady estate: the average of data obtained in the first 500 min of the reaction, steady state: the average of data obtained in the range of 500–1950 min]. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Yield to primary, secondary and tertiary products: a) yield to octene isomers, b) yield to aromatic products, c) yield to cracked products. (Reaction conditions: Temperature = 550 °C, GHSV = 11000 h−1 and n-octane concentration in the feed = 11.5%, Unsteady estate: the average of data obtained in the first 500 min of the reaction). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 The correlation between surface basicity, selectivity to cracked products and conversion over different magnesium molybdate catalysts under (unsteady state) DH conditions. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Raman spectra of the used catalysts with MM′0.87 (a), MM′0.98 (b), MM′1.06 (c) ′1.25 (d), under DH conditions and 11,000 h−1 GHSV. (*) MoC, (D) D band of graphite, (G) G band of graphite. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 TGA data of the used catalysts under a flow of air with MM′0.87 (a), MM′0.98 (b), MM′1.06 (c) and MM′1.25 (d), under DH conditions and 11,000 h−1 GHSV. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 The correlations between (a) surface basicity and the amount of deposited coke and (b) catalyst reducibility and the amount of formed MoC in the used catalysts after the time-on-stream (Unsteady estate: the average of data obtained in the first 500 min of the reaction) DH catalytic testing over magnesium molybdate catalysts. Fig. 10 Table 1 Molar ratio and BET surface area measurements for the catalysts. Table 1 Catalyst ICP-OES ratio (Mg:Mo) BET-surface area (m2 g−1) Basic sites a CO2 (cm3/STP) MM′0.87 1:0.87 3.2 4.7 MM′0.98 1:0.98 3.8 1.2 MM′1.06 1:1.06 4.2 0.9 MM′1.25 1:1.25 4.7 0.3 a CO2 TPD. Fadlalla Majid D. Farahani Holger B. Friedrich ⁎ Catalysis Research Group, School of Chemistry and Physics, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Westville Campus, Durban, 4000, South Africa Catalysis Research Group School of Chemistry and Physics University of KwaZulu-Natal Westville Campus Durban 4000 South Africa ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Dehydrogenation of paraffins is an industrially practiced technique for the production of value added olefins. Molybdenum based catalysts are known for this application. This study focuses on the application of magnesium molybdate based catalysts with different Mg:Mo ratios for the dehydrogenation of n-octane. Several characterisation techniques were utilised to investigate the physicochemical properties of the bulk as well as the surfaces of the fresh and used catalysts. Three active sites with different functionalities were identified for these materials in the chosen catalytic reaction. Reduced molybdenum oxide (Mo4+ and Mo5+) sites were responsible for dehydrogenation, whereas MgO (involved in the MgMoO4 lattice or as the MgO phase) modified the density of basic sites that strongly controlled the adsorption of n-octane. Finally, acidic sites (likely from molybdenum oxides) promoted cracking and played an indirect role in increasing coke deposition over these materials. A mechanism that involves the simultaneous operation of these three active sites is proposed. The ratio between MgMoO4 and MoO3 was found to strongly influence the redox transition and thermal stability of these phases. The discussed science in this study can be used as a tool for preparation of advanced molybdenum based catalysts for different catalytic applications. Keywords Magnesium molybdate Dehydrogenation Surface acidity Surface basicity Coke formation 1 Introduction Dehydrogenation of paraffins to light olefins is a commercial process since the 1940’s, mainly to produce C2-C4 olefins. Light olefins are a key component in the chemical industry, since they are used as building blocks (e.g. for polymers, oxygenates and fine chemicals). Due to the importance of dehydrogenation processes currently, there are 14 plants worldwide (e.g. the Catofin and Oleflex processes) [1]. However, the activation of medium chain length (C6 - C12) n-paraffins has become an interesting topic both academically and industrially, due to mainly: (1) the increase in the number of gas to liquid (GTL) and coal to liquid (CTL) plants worldwide, which caused the number of n-paraffins produced to increase and (2) paraffins can be used as starting materials for the production of economically and industrially important feed-stocks, such as olefins and aromatics [2–6]. These plants mainly use Cr-based and Pt-based catalysts. However, Cr based catalysts are associated with rapid deactivation and the formation of Cr6+ which is carcinogenic [7,8]. On the other hand, Pt-based catalysts are expensive. Molybdates with different cations gained a great deal of interest in various fields, such as in the battery industry, in the coating industry [9] and in catalysis. For example, iron molybdate is commercially used in the production of formaldehyde from methanol [10]. The molybdate structure is very important in its several distinct applications and has been proven to be different when various bivalent or trivalent cations were placed in the A position of AMoO4, with different molybdate phases [2,5,11,12]. In the case of magnesium molybdate, molybdenum occupies a distorted tetrahedral coordination site (isotopic to ZnMoO4) in the α-phase and tetrahedral geometry in the β-phase (isotopic to α-MnMoO4) [13]. Regarding magnesium molybdate structural polymorphisms, Sleight et al. [14] showed that molybdenum in MgMoO4 would favour the tetrahedral geometry due to the very close cell dimension in the MgMoO4, compared to CoMoO4 and NiMoO4 where molybdenum can be in octahedral geometry. Mo-based catalysts have been explored for the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of paraffins such as ethane [12], propane [15], n-butane [16], n-hexane [2,5] and n-octane [17]. ODH is an endothermic reaction and overcomes the equilibrium conversion limitations in dehydrogenation processes by using the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction [18]. However, low selectivity to desired products and deep oxidation of the introduced paraffin to COx is the major drawback of this system, which limits the application of Mo-based catalysts for ODH on a commercial scale. Extensive research on both dehydrogenation (DH) and oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) is focused on molybdenum oxide (MoO3) since it is environmentally friendly and economical [19–21]. DH is a safer process since there is no need to maintain a specific oxygen to paraffin ratio. The production of H2 is an advantage and DH is more selective to the target product since there is no risk of over-oxidation to COx. This has lead to commercialisation of DH and not ODH [8]. Wang et al. [8] studied isobutane DH over Mo/MgAl2O3, and found the active phase for DH to be a Mo4+ species. The yield to isobutene decreased as the Mo loading decreased with a maximum yield of isobutene obtained with 5 wt% Mo/MgAl2O3, which corresponds to a monolayer coverage of Mo on MgAl2O3 [22]. Increasing the calcination temperature of the catalyst with the monolayer MoO3 coverage lead to an increase in catalyst activity and a decrease in selectivity with the opposite trend observed with calcination temperature increase for a higher loading of MoO3 (30% MoO3/MgAl2O3). This was linked to changes in catalyst acidity, reducibility and surface area. Harlin et al. [7] studied the effect of Mg content in Mo/Al2O3 catalysts in n-butane DH. The increase in Mg content resulted in a decrease in n-butane conversion and selectivity to C1-C3, while the selectivity to the C4 alkene increased. This was attributed to Mg altering catalyst acidity and the reduction route of Mo. Also, all reported catalysts in these studies contained high concentration of the Al2(MoO4)3 phase that can have a profound impact on their DH performances [7,22]. To the best of our knowledge, no DH study on the bulk MgMoO4 has been done where the significant physicochemical properties of the supports are absent. Other molybdenum containing materials such as a hybrid catalyst containing Mo2C and nitrogen doped anion-like carbon (NOLC) for ethylbenzene DH [23] and in isobutane DH [24] have also been studied. This study shows the first application of MgMoO4 for the DH of n-octane. The effects of Mg and Mo content of this catalyst in the DH of n-octane were explored using several physical and chemical characterisation techniques. Time on stream analysis at a single temperature (550 °C) was chosen for all catalysts to probe the structure-performance link for these catalysts under the DH reaction conditions. Some new insights regarding the important factors controlling the DH of paraffins over Mo-based catalysts are proposed, after also characterizing the used catalysts. Also, thanks to the application of n-octane as the paraffin feed, the impact of Mg:Mo ratios on the dehydrocyclization reactions to form aromatic compounds is also discussed in this study. Mg addition was found to improve the n-octane activation, which consequently affected the selectivity to different products and coking. Also, synergic effects between magnesium, molybdenum and acidic sites are discussed and a mechanism for the DH of n-octane over these catalysts is proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Four magnesium molybdate (MM′) [M: magnesium and M′: molybdenum] catalysts with different magnesium content were prepared by a co-precipitation method adopted from literature [25]. Two separate solutions of magnesium nitrate (0.5 M) and ammonia heptamolybdenum nitrate solution (0.5 M) were prepared in de-ionised water. The pH of the molybdenum solution was adjusted to 6 using aqueous ammonia (Saarchem) under continuous stirring. The magnesium nitrate was added drop-wise at room temperature. After complete addition of the magnesium nitrate solution, the mixture was heated to 90 °C and maintained until a white slurry was formed. The slurry was then dried in the oven at 110 °C for 12 h to yield the magnesium molybdate precursor. The precursor was then calcined at 550 °C for 2 h to yield the magnesium molybdate catalyst. The different ratios of Mo/Mg were obtained by varying the concentration of the initial molybdenum solution. 2.2 Catalyst characterisation The phase(s) present in the various catalysts were analysed by X-Ray diffraction (XRD) utilising a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer. The analyses were carried out with a 2° angle window from 10 to 70°, 40 kV and 40 mA and a Cu radiation source. The surface areas of the catalysts were determined by BET (Brunauer-Emmet-Teller) surface area measurements. All samples were degassed in a Micromeritics Sample Prep 060 under nitrogen flow at 200 °C overnight. The samples were then analysed using a Micromeritics Tristar II. Infra-red (IR) spectra of the catalysts were obtained utilising a PerkinElmer Precisely equipped with a universal attenuated total reflection (ATR) sample holder. The Raman analyses were carried out using an Advantage 532 series spectrometer with Nuspec software. The molar ratios of magnesium to molybdenum were determined by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) using a PerkinElmer Precisely Optima 5300 DV. The surface morphology of the catalysts was viewed using a Zeiss ultra plus scanning electron microscope (SEM). Samples were carbon coated before imaging. The TPR/O/R (Temperature Programmed Reduction-Oxidation-Reduction) analysis was carried out by heating the catalyst under helium flow to 400 ᴼC and cooling to 80 ᴼC prior to the experiment and thereafter reduction analysis started by using 5% H2 in argon as a reducing gas with a flow rate of 30 ml/min using a Micromeritics 2920 Autochem II analyser. The hydrogen consumption was quantified based on the calibration done in the instrument using AgO as a standard. The TPO (Temperature Programmed Oxidation) analysis was carried over the reduced sample by cooling it down to 80 ᴼC and a similar method (as for TPR) was followed, the only difference was the analysis gas which is 5% O2 in helium. After that, another TPR (as detailed above) was carried out. CO2-TPD analysis was also done using a Micromeritics 2920 Autochem II analyser where the sample was dosed by CO2 for 30 min at 80 °C. Then, the sample was flushed isothermally using helium to remove the physisorbed CO2 from the surfaces of these catalysts. Finally, the sample was heated from 80 °C to 900 °C to measure the amount of desorbed CO2. TGA (Thermo-Gravimetric Analysis) was done in a TA instrument (SDT Q600). XPS (X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy) analysis was carried out using a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer, with an achromatic Al Kα source operated at 120 W. The base pressure in the analysis chamber was maintained at about 1 × 10−9 mbar. Pass energies of 160 eV and 40 eV were used for the acquisition of survey and detailed regional scans, respectively. Binding energies were calibrated against the C (1s) signal from adventitious carbon contamination, which was assumed to have a binding energy of 284.7 eV. 2.3 Catalytic testing All catalytic testing was carried out as time online analyses for 32 h iso-thermally at 500 °C. The reactor used was a continuous flow fixed bed reactor operated in vertical mode. The catalyst (0.5 ml (∼0.6 g) with a particle size between 600–1000 μm) was diluted with the same volume of carborundum (40 gritt <355 μm) and placed in a stainless steel tube at the hot spot of the reactor. The temperature of the catalyst bed was monitored by a thermocouple that was placed in the vertical axis. n-Octane (98%, Alfa Aesar) was introduced into the reactor lines (pre-heated to 140 °C) utilising a series II HPLC (High Performance Liquid Chromatography) pump. The gas eluent from the reactor was measured by a Ritter drum-type gas flow meter. The liquid eluent was collected in a catch pot pre-cooled to 5 °C, base line grade nitrogen was used to adjust the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) at 11,000 h−1 and give an n-octane concentration of 11.5% in the feed. All gaseous and liquid samples were analysed using a Shimadzu 2121 GC with FID (Flame Ionization Detector) and PONA capillary column. The n-octane conversion and product selectivity were calculated as shown in Eqs. (1) and (2) respectively. In unsteady state, carbon balances of 97 ± 1% were observed for all catalysts due to coke deposition. The observed carbon balances for steady-state conditions were improved (100 ± 1%). (1) Conversion = m o l e o f o c t a n e i n − m o l e o c t a n e o u t m o l e o f o c t a n e i n × 100 (2) Selectivity = M o l e s o f c a r b o n i n p r o d u c t T o t a l m o l e s o f c a r b o n i n p r o d u c t s × 100 2.4 Used catalyst characterization After the reaction, the catalysts were cooled and kept under N2 and characterised using Raman spectroscopy and TGA under a flow of air. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The XRD (Fig. 1 ) patterns revealed the formation of the MgMoO4 (monoclinic, C2/m) phase accompanied by MoO3 (monoclinic, P21/n). Comparison between the 021 (β-MgMoO4) and the 201 (α-MgMoO4) planes, showed that the dominating phase in the magnesium molybdate is the β-MgMoO4. This is because the pH was maintained at six during the syntheses, and also that the catalysts were calcined at 550 °C. Yoon et al. [26] had previously shown that the synthesis pH and calcination temperature affect the ratio of the α-MgMoO4 and β-MgMoO4 phases. ICP-OES results and the BET-surface area measurements (Table 1 ) show that as the molybdenum content increases in the catalysts, the surface area increases (to a small degree), as also noted for magnesium molybdate and cobalt molybdate [27]. Furthermore, no peaks for MgO were detected for Mg rich catalysts probably due to its small crystallite size. IR spectra of the different catalysts (Supplementary information, Fig. S1) showed the bands for MgMoO4 at 935 cm−1 (shoulder) and 885 cm−1 (strong) corresponding to Vas (MoOMo), in addition to bands at 811 cm−1 and 725 cm−1 corresponding to Vas (MoO). These bands were observed together with two bands for the terminal MoO and δMoO in MoO3 at 767 cm−1 and 409 cm−1, respectively [26,28]. The Raman spectra show the MoO bending at ∼346 cm−1 in all catalysts. The characteristic band of molybdenum trioxide was observed in all catalysts at ∼815 cm−1 (Ag, B1g) assigned to a symmetric stretch of the terminal oxygen atoms (Fig. 2 , Table 2 ) [29]. The presence of the MgMoO4 was confirmed further by the bands at ∼852, 903 (asymmetric MoO) and 959 cm−1 (symmetric MoO). The ratio in intensity between the characteristic band for molybdenum trioxide (∼815 cm−1) and that of magnesium molybdate (∼959 cm−1) indicated the ratio in which the two phases are present in the catalyst [30]. The increase in the molybdenum content in the catalyst (determined by ICP-OES) leads to a rise in the I 815/I 959, showing that the excess molybdenum in the magnesium molybdate catalyst is present in the molybdenum trioxide phase. To stablish the metallic properties of Mo in this study, H2-TPR analysis was done. The TPR profiles for the different catalysts (Fig. 3 a–d) all showed two peaks, the first peak at around 650 °C (due to reduction of MoO3 with Mo in the 6+ state) and the second in the region 900–950 °C (due to the reduction of the magnesium molybdate phase with Mo in the 6+ state). As shown by the XPS data later, no MoO2 is in the fresh catalysts, showing Mo species are in their highest oxidised state (6+). The first peak intensity decreased as the magnesium content increases in the catalyst (Fig. 3a–d), indicating that the Mg addition resulted in the greater formation of the MgMoO4 phase (second peak in H2-TPR analyses) in these catalysts. Moreover, the hydrogen consumption for the second peak also increased as the molybdenum content increased, this could be a subsequent reduction of the initial reduction product since MoO2 is known to reduce in this region [31]. However, the H2 consumption of the second peak was lower for MM′1.25 and did not follow the same trend as was observed for the other catalysts. Pioneering work by Ressler et al. showed that MoO3 can directly be reduced to Moo at ∼450 °C under suitable conditions [32]. Considering the difference between the H2-TPR data of MM′1.25 and the other catalysts, the ratio between MgMoO4 and MoO3 seems to be very important in altering the Mo6+→ Mo4+ transition to the Mo6+→ Moo transition (at approximately the same temperature) for these materials. Therefore, this finding demonstrates that careful attention needs to be paid to the reaction of phases in biphasic Mo-based catalysts when considering the application of Mo-based materials for different catalytic systems. Furthermore, the different composition of the catalysts resulted in shifts of the second peak to a lower reduction temperature as the amount of MoO3 increased in the catalyst (Table 3 ) [25]. TPR-O-R analyses of catalysts MM′0.98 and MM′1.25 (Fig. 3e and f, respectively) showed that in the reduction cycle after oxidation only one peak is present. The peak that is believed to be due to reduction of MoO3 to MoO2 in the first TPR was no longer present, because the reduction of molybdenum trioxide to molybdenum dioxide is not reversible (i.e. MoO2 cannot be oxidised under these conditions). However, the magnesium molybdate phase undergoes reversible reduction, oxidation and reduction, unlike the molybdenum trioxide phase. Fig. 4 shows the peaks, obtained from XPS, with binding energies of Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 of the prepared catalysts with different Mg/Mo ratios. The binding energies of Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 for all the catalysts were located at 232 and 235 eV, respectively, which agree with the literature [33]. With the increase in the Mg/Mo ratios there is not much difference in these binding energies (Table 4 ). These peaks are associated with Mo6+ ions in all the catalysts [33]. The analysis of the O 1s core levels of these catalysts showed two dominant peaks (Table 4). The first one, with a binding energy of 530 eV, is assigned to the O2− ions that are involved in MO bonds in the structures of MgMoO4 [33,34]. The second peak at ∼531.5 eV is the result of OH groups on the surfaces of these catalysts [33,34]. The investigation of the Mg 2p lines showed an increase in binding energies with the increase of Mg content of these catalysts. This shift in the binding energy of the Mg 2p core levels of these catalysts indicates that the formation of the hydroxylated surface is promoted when the Mg content of these catalysts was higher [35,36]. Therefore, the higher the concentration of Mg, the greater the concentrations of hydroxyl groups (basic sites) on the surfaces of these Mg containing catalysts, which correlates well to the CO2-TPD data shown in Table 1. The Mg/Mo ratios agree with the ICP results (Table 4). The SEM imaging (Fig. S2, Supplementary information) showed the plate-like particles associated with MoO3 and the size of these plates increases as the Mo content in the catalyst increases, supporting the increase in MoO3 content observed from the Raman, ICP-OES and TPR results. The mapping analysis of the surface of the catalyst by SEM shows a homogeneous distribution of the metals (Mg and Mo) on the surface. As the Mo content in the catalyst increases, more Mo appears on the surface, which was expected. No MgO particles were seen for the Mg-rich catalyst (MM′0.87), possibly due to its amorphous nature, since XRD was also unable to detect it. The absence of MgO peaks indicates the high tendency of Mg cations to incorporate in the molybdenum oxide structure and form a bimetallic magnesium molybdate phase, which is also discussed in other reports [11,15]. 3.2 Catalytic testing The increase in Mg content of these catalysts seems to improve the n-octane conversion. Although this difference is more pronounced under unsteady state conditions (the first 500 min of reaction), this effect seems to be present even under steady state conditions (after 500 min of reaction). In addition, MM′1.25 (with the lowest Mg content) deactivated faster than the other catalysts (Fig. 5 ), possibly due to in situ formation of Moo, that was seen using H2-TPR analysis, that deactivated much faster due to coking. Generally, the increase of Mg content of these catalysts resulted in higher selectivity to octene isomers under the unsteady state conditions. However, in steady state, MM′1.25 showed the highest selectivity to octenes, possibly due to the low population of active sites over this catalyst after coking, since Moo sites are expected to coke severely. Under the unsteady state condition, MM′1.25 showed the highest selectivity towards aromatics when compared to the other catalysts. All catalysts showed increasing trends to cracked products over time. Also, MM′1.25, with the lowest Mg content and activity, showed the lowest selectivity to these cracked products. This observation suggests that the responsible sites (with acidic nature) for cracking are different from the dehydrogenation sites [Mo4+ and Mo5+] [7] (responsible for octenes and C8 aromatics formation) and that these acidic sites (responsible for cracking) are protected from coke deposition, whereas the DH sites experienced coking. Also, despite the facile reduction of MoO3 in comparison to MgMoO4, the former phase showed poor catalytic performance. This reveals the positive role of MgO (in the MgMoO4 lattice or as amorphous MgO) in this catalysis. Therefore, MgMoO4 can be referred to as a desired phase to obtain a high activity and selectivity to octene isomers, whereas MoO3 seems to promote the dehydrocyclization reaction. Differentiating the contribution of α-MgMoO4 from β-MgMoO4 in the DH reaction is out of the scope of the current study. The deposited coke under the steady conditions covers most of the features of the catalysts (discussed later). Therefore, the selectivities towards different octenes, aromatics and cracked products were only investigated under the unsteady state conditions. During the unsteady state conditions, the first 500 min of the reaction, for all catalyst, the selectivity to octene isomers increased whereas the aromatic selectivity decreased. The deep dehydrogenation and dehydrocyclization of the octenes over the highly active reduced Mo sites for DH resulted in aromatic formation over these catalysts. The activity of these sites decreased due to coke deposition, which will be discussed later using the TGA of the used catalysts; therefore, the selectivity to aromatic products decreased and higher selectivity to octene isomers was obtained as a function of time. The yield towards all types of octene isomers decreased when the Mo content of these catalysts was increased (Fig. 6 a). In contrast, the overall yield to aromatic products increased as the Mo content of these catalysts increased. For all catalysts, ethylbenzene is the dominant aromatic, which is followed by o-xylene and styrene (Fig. 6b). The yield of styrene also increased upon increase of Mo content of the MM′ catalysts. The 2, 3 and 4-octenes are known as thermodynamically favoured products, whereas 1-octene is a kinetically stable olefin. These data show that Mo addition increases the residence time of the formed olefins on the DH active sites of these catalysts, due to increased acidity, due to the Mo addition, which is well-established in the literature [37]. As a result, aromatics were seen in higher relative population, whereas octene isomers seem to be reabsorbed on acidic sites and follow the dehydro-cyclisation pathway to form aromatics when the Mo content of these catalysts increases. Higher acidity is known to promote the cracking of formed olefins during the DH of paraffins. Despite this expectation, the cracking seems to increase upon the increase of Mg (with basic properties) content of these catalysts (Fig. 6c). Thus, increasing basicity via Mg addition seems to facilitate the formation of C8 olefins, whereas the present acidic sites over these catalysts seem only to crack these formed olefins. Preservation of these acidic sites from coking and the increasing trend toward cracking upon the increase of Mg content reveals interesting mechanistic aspects of the DH reaction over these catalysts. The DH sites have the potential to contribute to four sequential reactions of the C8 hydrocarbons. These possible reactions are the DH of the paraffin, the DH of the formed olefins, the DH of dienes and the DH of ethylbenzene [38]. The adsorption of n-octane seems to be facilitated by increasing the Mg content of the catalysts, while the residence times of the formed olefins, dienes and aromatics have a direct correlation with Mo content of these catalysts. However, the majority of reported Mo-based catalysts showed a poisoning effect of Mg addition on the activity. Our obtained data in this study confirmed the conclusions from these past studies (supported Mo systems) that the acidity is mainly originated from the used supports rather than Mg and Mo sites on those catalysts. In contrast, the cracking sites only re-adsorb the formed olefins and break their CC bonds. Alkanes are less reactive than alkenes, which implies that the formed products with double bonds in the DH reaction are more prone to cracking. However, the presence of conjugated cyclised systems with several resonance structures provided sufficient stability for aromatic products to be preserved from cracking caused by acidic MoOx sites [39]. Therefore, the higher the yield to olefins, the greater the cracking reaction. Also, the DH activity of these sites seems to be low, which results in their protection from coking. Since MgO species (as the MgO phase or in the MgMoO4 lattice) have basic nature [3,15,40], it can be proposed that cracking reactions take place over MoO3 with known acidic character, which further proves the direct correlation of the yield to olefins and the extent of the cracking reaction over aforementioned acidic sites [37]. As shown in Table 1, there is a direct correlation between the Mg content of the catalysts and their surface basicity. Fig. 7 shows the correlation between the surface basicity and conversion, as well as the selectivity to cracked products under the unsteady state DH conditions. Generally, as the surface basicity increases, both of n-octane conversion and selectivity to cracked products increases. It seems that the adsorption of n-octane on the surface of the MM′ catalysts increases as the Mg content and surface basicity is raised. The present basic sites (MgOx) in higher concentration seem to promote the desorption rate of the olefins from the DH site, and then, a part of formed olefins feed the acidic sites resulting in a greater rate of cracking. So, Mg addition increases the conversion indirectly via Le Chatelier’s rule by faster desorption of products from the DH sites. Moreover, the selectivity to cracked products increased since the primary products, which have greater reactivity, are formed in larger quantity, and can reabsorbed on non-dehydrogenating acidic sites that are known for their high cracking potential under the chosen catalytic conditions [3,7,40]. Therefore, the adsorption of n-octane, which takes place before the hydrogen abstraction, seems to be the rate determining step for the DH over the magnesium molybdate materials. Mo4+ and Mo5+ are known active sites for dehydrogenation on these catalysts [7]. In spite of n-octane being a stronger reducing agent than H2, only partial reduction of the surface of these catalysts can be discussed under the chosen conditions since coke deposition over the surface of these catalysts prevents the diffusion of gaseous n-octane to the interior sites of the existing pores in these catalysts. The adsorption of the reactant can be suggested as the rate-determining step in this system, where the concentration of the active site for DH is low or the site is possibly partially covered by coke in the cases of MM′1.06 and MM′1.25, in both unsteady and steady state conditions. The concentration of acidic and basic sites over the surface of the material is known to have a direct influence on the adsorption rate of the selected catalytic systems. Also, the acidity of the surface is usually different when the catalyst is in an oxide or reduced state [15]. Determination of the density of the acidic sites using ex situ techniques can be misleading in this study since, unlike supported Mo-based catalysts, the majority of acidic character of these catalysts is supplied by Mo species, while in the supported systems, supports mainly contributed towards the seen surface acidity. As shown thus far, molybdenum species are partially reduced and TGA of the used catalysts also suggested (as discussed in the characterisation of the used catalysts [Section 3.4]) that MoC species are also formed during the catalytic evaluations. Both these factors prevent the accurate measurement of the acidity using ex situ analysis in this study. On the other hand, the basic sites can be estimated using CO2-TPD, since MgO is an irreducible oxide and remains stable during the DH reaction [3,40,41]. Since the basic sites of these catalysts increased as their Mg content increased (Table 1), it seems that the presence of Mg in these catalysts, irrespective of phase composition, correlated with the observed basicity as also was discussed by Yoon et al. [15]. 3.3 Used catalyst characterisation Usually, the analysis of the formed coke on the surface of the catalysts can provide meaningful insight about the nature of active sites during the catalytic applications. Raman and TGA analyses were used to characterise the different types of coke formed over the MM′ catalysts. Four distinct peaks for the used MM′ catalysts were observed in the Raman spectra (Fig. 8 ). The peaks at 820 and 1000 cm−1 are indicative of the formation of MoC during the catalytic reaction [42]. The peaks at 1320 and 1590 cm−1 can be assigned to the D and G bands of disordered and ordered graphitised carbons, respectively [43]. The Raman spectra further showed (Fig. 8) that coke formation has a direct correlation with the Mg content of the catalysts. Since the Raman analysis is seen as qualitative, TGA analysis under a flow of air was used to gain more insight into the amount of the deposited coke. The TGA data (under air flow) showed a mass gain at ∼ 433 °C, which corresponds to the decomposition of the MoC phase and formation of molybdenum dioxide (Fig. 9 ) [42]. The mass lost in the temperature range of ∼433 °C – 700 °C is due to combustion of the formed coke over these catalysts. All catalysts, except MM′1.25, showed similar TGA plots. The TGA analysis of the used MM′1.25 showed the lowest amount of deposited coke, which was expected from the observed small peak in the Raman analysis. This catalyst also showed a 13.6% mass loss at relatively high temperatures (above 800 °C), which is due to the decomposition of the MoO3 in this catalyst [44]. However, the MoO3 in the other catalysts did not decompose during the TGA analysis. This shows that MoO3-MgMoO4 ratios are also an important factor in phase stability in these catalysts, as was discussed earlier in this work for the phase reduction. From the characterisation of the used catalysts and the catalytic results, one can further conclude that the Mg addition improves the n-octane adsorption, since the amounts of deposited coke and Mg content showed similar trends. Also, this greater adsorption of n-octane on the surface resulted in higher conversion as well as more crystalline graphite coke over these catalysts. Lower activities were observed over catalysts with higher Mo content (MM′1.06 and MM′1.25), possibly due to the presence of MoO3 and in situ formed Moo. The MoO3 phase seems to lower the paraffin adsorption and as a result lower the activity. However, this phase and the coked Moo seem to be responsible for a longer residence time of the formed olefins due to their acidic nature and give a higher selectivity towards aromatic products [19]. The formation of MoC and coke on the surface of all catalysts was found to be the main reason for the low activity during the steady-state conditions. Fig. 10 a shows the correlation between the surface basicity (obtained using CO2-TPD data), conversion and coking. Coking increases with increasing surface basicity (due to greater adsorption of n-octane) and conversion, which corresponds well to the observed trend for cracking (Fig. 6). This confirms that the acidic sites are secondary contributors to both cracking and coking reactions, whereas the basic sites (MgO species) and reduced Mo species are primary contributors since MgO sites facilitate the adsorption and desorption process of the feed and formed products, respectively, over the reduced Mo sites, which feed the acidic sites that cause the aforementioned undesired reactions (Figs. 6 and 10a). This indicates that acidic sites induce some secondary effects that indirectly accelerate the coke deposition process over these catalysts. Also, the catalysts (MM′0.87, MM′0.98 and MM′1.06) with greater H2 consumption values (from H2-TPR analyses) showed a higher amount of formed MoC (from TGA analyses) (Fig. 10b). This shows that carbon diffuses into the molybdenum structure to a greater extent when a higher quantity of reducible Mo6+ is accessible on the surface, which further confirms that reduced MoOx species are the desired adducts for MoC formation. However, the formed Moo during the testing does not seem to be the precursor for MoC formation, since a lower quantity of this phase was determined for MM′1.25 considering the TGA data (Fig. 9). Scheme 1 a shows the proposed reaction mechanism for the DH of n-octane over the magnesium molybdate catalysts. The first step in the activation of n-octane is its adsorption on the surface of the MM′ catalyst. MgO addition increased the surface basicity as well as the adsorption of feed. Hydrogen abstraction using reduced molybdenum is the second step. Since the conversion under unsteady conditions varied when Mg content changed, it can be concluded that the adsorption of feed was the rate determining step in this study. Octenes and aromatics (DH products) were desorbed from the surface in the third step. However, some of these primary products (with high activity) were re-adsorbed on the acidic sites, which promoted the cracking as well as, indirectly, the coking. Surprisingly, the acidic sites were not coked, which indicated their indirect role in coking as shown in Scheme 1b, where the catalyst showed its lowest performance and operated under steady state. 4 Conclusion Four catalysts were investigated with varying Mg content (i.e. MM′0.87, MM′0.98, MM′1.06 and MM′1.25). The ratios between the MoO3 and MgMoO4 phases were found to switch the reduction transition of Mo6+→ Mo4+ to Mo6+→ Moo (at almost the same temperature) and also modify the phase stabilities of these catalysts. The main effect introduced by the Mg content is the alteration of catalyst surface concentration of molybdenum, which in turn influenced the selectivity of the catalysts. The n-octane conversion and selectivity to octenes increased over the catalysts in the order MM′0.87 > MM′0.98 ∼ MM′1.06 > MM′1.25 and thus showed a direct correlation with Mg content of these catalysts. The effect of Mg content was evident especially under unsteady state of the catalyst (before coke alters the catalyst surface). A finding of this study shows Mg addition increases the basicity of the surfaces of the catalyst, which increases both n-octane adsorption and conversion over the surfaces of these catalysts. Moreover, the increase in conversion and, hence, primary products gave increased secondary adsorption on the acidic sites, which in return promoted the undesired coking and cracking reactions. Also, a mechanism that involves three synergised active sites, which are the basic sites of MgO (responsible for the adsorption of feed), reduced molybdenum (responsible for dehydrogenation) and acidic sites (responsible for cracking and coking reactions) is proposed. The findings of this study introduce key parameters that can be beneficial in designing Mo based catalysts for different catalytic reactions. coredata.dc:description: Dehydrogenation of paraffins is an industrially practiced technique for the production of value added olefins. Molybdenum based catalysts are known for this application. This study focuses on the application of magnesium molybdate based catalysts with different Mg:Mo ratios for the dehydrogenation of n-octane. Several characterisation techniques were utilised to investigate the physicochemical properties of the bulk as well as the surfaces of the fresh and used catalysts. Three active sites with different functionalities were identified for these materials in the chosen catalytic reaction. Reduced molybdenum oxide (Mo4+ and Mo5+) sites were responsible for dehydrogenation, whereas MgO (involved in the MgMoO4 lattice or as the MgO phase) modified the density of basic sites that strongly controlled the adsorption of n-octane. Finally, acidic sites (likely from molybdenum oxides) promoted cracking and played an indirect role in increasing coke deposition over these materials. A mechanism that involves the simultaneous operation of these three active sites is proposed. The ratio between MgMoO4 and MoO3 was found to strongly influence the redox transition and thermal stability of these phases. The discussed science in this study can be used as a tool for preparation of advanced molybdenum based catalysts for different catalytic applications.
coredata.dc:title: Three inter-linked active sites in the dehydrogenation of n-octane over magnesium molybdate based catalysts and their influences on coking and cracking side reactions
